text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
(1) (1) This transmits revised IRM 9.4.13, Financial Investigative Task Force
IRM is revised to include all investigative task forces Criminal Investigation (CI) special agents in along with the instructions for preparing a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU).

Subsections throughout the manual are revised to reflect the nature of the changes that are related to the change of the previous Organized Crime and Drug Enforcement Task Force (OCDETF) Coordinators to Organized Crime and Drug Enforcement Task Force/Counterterrorism (OCDETF/CT) Coordinators with additional duties concerning Counterterrorism. There is also clarification of the roles of participants at different levels of the OCDETF program.

Subsections throughout the manual are revised to reflect the nature of the changes that are related to the change of the previous Organized Crime and Drug Enforcement Task Force (OCDETF) Coordinators to Organized Crime and Drug Enforcement Task Force/Counterterrorism (OCDETF/CT) Coordinators with additional duties concerning Counterterrorism. There is also clarification of the roles of participants at different levels of the OCDETF program.

Subsection 9.4.13.2 provides updated guidance relative to the OCDETF Program. This subsection also provides updated guidance for the Reimbursement to State and Local Law Enforcement officers when their participation is key to joint operations with CI and the types of expenses that qualify for reimbursement along with the necessary forms and procedures for processing such requests.
Subsection 9.4.13.4 provides guidance on non-OCDETF narcotics investigations and High Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA).
Subsection 9.4.13.6 provides guidance relative to the Organized Crime and Strike Force task forces.
Subsection 9.4.13.7 contains guidance relative to the Financial Investigative Task Force (FITF).

Subsection 9.4.13.7.1 is revised to reflect procedures to be followed in the operation of Financial Investigative Task Force investigations and delete references to the process to request deputation of Task Force Officers by US Marshals Service.
Subsection 9.4.13.7.2 is revised to reflect new procedures to be followed when requesting detail of state and/or local law enforcement officers to work with IRS Criminal Investigation.
9.4.13.9 is revised to reflect current procedures for the preparation and approval of the used by CI for the participation in joint operations with other agencies.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.4.13, Financial Investigative Task Force, dated March 4, 2003. contained in IRM 9.5.6, Organized Crime & Strike Force, dated July 29, 2002, and IRM 9.5.7, Investigations, dated August 1, 2003, have been merged into this IRM and are now obsolete.

This section provides guidance relative to Criminal Investigation’s (CI) partici

pation in investigative task forces. The task forces discussed in detail in this section are not all inclusive. This section includes general instructions for CI’s participation in any task force developed to address a particular area of concern which falls within CI’s jurisdiction, such as developing and processing a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). Memorandums of Understanding are necessary to ensure that CI’s policies and procedures regarding such matters as informants, case documentation, undercover operations, asset forfeiture and other sensitive areas are consistently applied. ) Special agents will be assigned to a task force by CI management on an as- needed basis. Special agents assigned to a task force remain subject to all the policies and procedures of CI, to include the updated IRS Structuring Investi- gation Policy issued on October
In addition, special agents must participate in required training and management oversight meetings as directed. (

) Criminal Investigation does not permit its special agents to be cross- designated. It makes no difference whether an agent is assigned to an OCDETF or HIDTA, a special agent is not permitted to investigate violations that are not specifically outlined in IRM

All of the authority necessary to conduct financial-related inves- tigations is conveyed to those special agents assigned to and participating in national task forces by the IRS, and in some instances, highlighted by various MOUs negotiated by local IRS management and various local task forces. Criminal Investigation special agents participate on national task forces as federal law enforcement officers operating within the statutory and investigative jurisdiction of the IRS. Notwithstanding IRS jurisdictions and policies, participa- tion in an investigative task force occasionally requires participants to perform investigative tasks and activities for the benefit of and assistance to the entire task force. Consequently, it is permissible for special agents with the appropri- ate CI management approval to, as an example, assist the task force with the service of subpoenas, conduct interviews with third party witnesses, or assist with the execution of a search warrant, even though CI has no open Primary Investigation (PI) or Subject Criminal Investigation (SCI). ) The Criminal Investigation Narcotics Program supports CI’s participation in OCDETF and HIDTA investigations of members of high-level drug trafficking organizations. Additionally, the narcotics program includes HIDTA and localized need investigations that involve the financial activities of individuals who transport, distribute, or finance illegal drugs or launder signifi- cant illegal drug proceeds. (

) The goal of the OCDETF Program is to identify, investigate, and prosecute transnational, national, and regional criminal drug organizations most respon- sible for the illegal drug supply in the US and the diversion of licit drugs. organizations include the international supply sources, their international and domestic transportation organizations, their regional and local distribution networks, their money launderers and financial infrastructure, and their violent enforcers. The OCDETF seeks to disrupt and dismantle every component of these drug trafficking networks in order to reduce the drug supply in the US and diminish the violence and other drug-related criminal activity associated with these organizations. (

) Significant drug trafficking and money laundering organizations include the ganizations identified as Consolidated Priority Organization Target (CPOT) as well as each individual region’s Regional Priority Organization Target (RPOT). (
) Each of the nine OCDETF regions has its own organizational identity with an Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) coordinator, located in that region’s core city. (

) Criminal Investigation maintains a national coordinator who liaises with the OCDETF executive office and regional coordinators who liaise with each of other agency coordinators for each OCDETF region. (

In addition, the investigations should possess the following characteristics: a. Investigations that warrant the involvement of more than one federal in- vestigative agency, or of one federal investigative agency and one or international law enforcement agencies, with limited exceptions as described below b. Investigations that demand significant attorney resources during the tigative stage. Examples include matters involving electronic or the extensive use of the grand jury; matters emanating from the Operations Division (SOD); the presence of substantial cash or property likely to be subject to forfeiture; the likelihood of income tax violations, plea agreements with underlings or possible witness protection issues underlings; and the corruption of public officials c. Investigations that focus on high-level prosecutions and also on dismantling the financial infrastructure of the targeted organization through the seizure and forfeiture of money, conveyances, real estate, businesses, or other non-drug assets d. Investigations that are expected to result in the conviction of persons engaged in regional, national, or international organized activities to the importation, manufacture, distribution, crop cultivation, diversion, sale, financial support, and/or money laundering associated with the trafficking of any illegal drug or narcotic substance, as well as ticals trafficking and the diversion, purchase, and use of precursor chemicals e. Investigations that are related to, or are linked to, or have the potential link to, a simultaneous OCDETF investigation in another district The preceding are general standards for the types of investigations that be accepted as task force investigations. ) The CI Program (CIP) Codes OCDETF, HIDTA OCDETF and Terrorism/ OCDETF have been assigned to track OCDETF activity under the Criminal Procedures for Investigation Management Information System (CIMIS). The CIP Code Crime and OCDETF (NAROC), tracks activity solely related to OCDETF investigations. Task The CIP Code HIDTA/OCDETF (HIDOC), tracks activity on investigations are related to both the HIDTA and OCDETF task forces. The CIP Code Terrorism/OCDETF (TERROCDETF) tracks activity on investigations that related to OCDETF with a terrorism component. (

) The Internal Revenue Service receives funding as part of its annual budget appropriation for IRS-CI’s participation in counter-narcotics related tions. In order to properly account for the investigative resources applied to counter-narcotics related investigations, all qualifying OCDETF investigative time must be input into CIMIS by either uploading the agent’s Diary entries directly into CIMIS or using the Form

, Criminal Investigation Monthly Activity Report, generated from the Diary to manually input into CIMIS. The qualifying OCDETF time is limited to qualifying task force investigative time all resources expended on an approved CI OCDETF investigation or tion and qualifying task force investigative time which includes all time to an approved OCDETF General Investigation (GI), PI or SCI. Note: When an open investigation subsequently becomes an approved investigation, all time charged within that same fiscal year and going will be charged as OCDETF time, even if the time was charged prior to approval to become an OCDETF investigation. If time was charged in a fiscal year while it was a non-OCDETF investigation, that time will not change to become OCDETF time. (

) Each OCDETF office, under the jurisdiction of DOJ, will be equipped with physical security measures wherein OCDETF members may review and and Personnel discuss information up to and including National Security information at the In Organized secret level. Drug (

) Technical IRS personnel assigned to work without escort within an Task Force office shall be clearable to the top secret security level and, when deemed Settings necessary, will be certified for top secret clearance and available to attend meetings in which top secret data is discussed and examined. Each of employees must have been the subject of a recently (within five years) completed full field background investigation favorably adjudicated. (
) Any CI employee requiring a security clearance or a clearance elevated to secret will follow the procedures on initiating or obtaining a security found on the CI Web site. (

) Routine involvement and assignment to OCDETF will not necessitate the issuance of a top secret security clearance. Top secret clearance requests should be initiated only for those technical personnel who are required to access or disseminate sensitive data which has been classified “top secret.” Clearances may also be granted for individuals required to attend briefings regarding OCDETF matters, if it is a requirement of the facility wherein the meeting is conducted. For these individuals, a memorandum requesting top secret clearance must also accompany the investigation documents. These submissions should be forwarded as expeditiously as possible through the background investigation coordinator, see obtaining a security clearance on CI Web site.

) The primary objective of the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) program is to analyze BSA filings and develop significant financial investigations, involving both Act and illegal source income. The BSA program supports interagency of BSA information to identify various types of criminal activity, including tax evasion, money laundering, narcotics trafficking and terrorist financing. (

) The BSA program within field offices consists of at least one Suspicious Activity Report-Review Team (SAR-RT) or a combination of at least one SAR-RT and one or more FCTFs: a. SAR-RT: This group is led by the USAO and is formed in each judicial district pursuant to the “Guide to Creating a Suspicious Activity Report Review Team” published by the Department of Justice in

CI assigns a special agent (BSA coordinator) to assist the USAO in the management of the SAR-RT. Many SAR-RTs are comprised of a multi- agency group of investigators and analysts that meet periodically for the sole purpose of reviewing SARs. The SAR-RT’s primary purpose is development. It does not routinely conduct criminal investigations; develops and refers cases for special agent assignment. b. Financial Crimes Task Force (FCTF): This group is created and led by and is comprised of detailed state and local law enforcement officers sometimes criminal investigators from other federal agencies. Financial Crimes Task Force personnel are often co-located and may seek from the TFF for space, operational expenses and certain equipment needs. State and local officers that join a FCTF are detailed to CI as criminal investigators and are referred to as TFOs. CI assigns an SSA manage the FCTF. Ensuring that the field office SAR-RT is made a part of group/branch op- erational reviews to determine and address the effectiveness of the program. ) A vital component to IRS-CI’s mission is the collaboration with the federal, state and local law enforcement communities pursuing asset forfeiture and financial crimes such as money laundering, currency violations, terrorist financing and narcotics related investigations. A key element to the success these partnerships is the use of MOUs. We are committed to providing our field offices with timely information that would allow IRS-CI participation in endeavors as soon as possible. (

) Whether or not CI is the lead agency of a task force, the use of an MOU other federal, state and local law enforcement and regulatory departments, offices or agencies facilitates CI participation in interagency task forces and high-profile, long-term, joint investigations. (

) The MOU establishes a common understanding of critical operational issues, including agency policies, investigative protocols, fiscal commitments, and liability issues within task forces, joint investigations and other enforcement initiatives between CI and other federal, state or local agencies. (

) When appropriate, the MOU should address CI’s policies and procedures regarding matters such as informants, case documentation, undercover tions, asset forfeiture, and other sensitive areas to ensure they are applied and are not disregarded. If the MOU is authored by another agency, that agency must be made aware that CI employees will participate within CI policies and procedures. (

) The MOU is a commitment by a SAC to commit resources. The availability those resources within CI’s fiscal plan must be considered and the finance section made aware of financial obligations and requirements.

) CI field offices may receive requests to de-conflict its cases and task force ac- tivities with proposed SBSE BSA examinations of Money Services Businesses (MSBs), credit unions, casinos, check cashiers and certain other non-regulated industries. Fi

EN has delegated BSA compliance authority over these Non- Bank Financial Institutions (NBFI) to IRS, which has re-delegated the authority to SBSE Fraud/BSA. CI field office BSA coordinators should take steps to de- conflict the proposed listing of examinations with on-going CI cases and task forces. (
